files.name: configuration.md
files.title: IMAP Configuration and Setup
files.content:
# IMAP Configuration and Setup


---

## üìÉ Default Configuration

>Both IMAP and POP3 have a large number of configuration options, making it difficult to deep dive into each component in more detail. If you wish to examine these protocol configurations deeper, we recommend creating a VM locally and install the two packages dovecot-imapd, and dovecot-pop3d using apt and play around with the configurations and experiment.
[core settings](https://doc.dovecot.org/2.4.1/core/summaries/settings.html)

## Methods

### Nmap IMAP

```bash
sudo nmap <ip_address> -sV -p110,143,993,995 -sC
```

files.name: configuration.md
files.title: MSSQL CONFIGURATION
files.content:
# MSSQL CONFIGURATION

## ‚ùå Dangerous Settings

- MSSQL clients not using encryption to connect to the MSSQL server

- The use of self-signed certificates when encryption is being used. It is possible to spoof self-signed certificates

- The use of [named pipes](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/sql/tools/configuration-manager/named-pipes-properties?view=sql-server-ver15)

- Weak & default sa credentials. Admins may forget to disable this account

## Methods

python3 mssqlclient.py <username>@<ip_address> -windows-auth
```

files.name: backup.sh
files.title: backup
files.content:
#!/bin/bash

# Configuration de la cible (√† adapter)
REMOTE_HOST="adresse.ip.de.l.appareil"
REMOTE_USER="utilisateur_ssh"
SOURCE_DIR="/volume1/dossier_a_sauvegarder/"
DEST_DIR="/chemin/distant/de/destination/"
LOG_FILE="/var/log/rsync_sync.log"

# --- Boucle de v√©rification de l'h√¥te ---
echo "$(date): Tentative de connexion √† $REMOTE_HOST..." >> $LOG_FILE

while ! ping -c 1 -W 1 $REMOTE_HOST > /dev/null 2>&1
do
    echo "$(date): H√¥te ($REMOTE_HOST) hors ligne. Attente de 5 minutes..." >> $LOG_

files.content:
# CONFIGURE AND SETUP SMB

## üìÉ Default Configuration

```bash
cat /etc/samba/smb.conf | grep -v "#\|\;"
```

Example output:
```bash
[global]
    workgroup = DEV.INFREIGHT.HTB
    server string = DEVSMB
    log file = /var/log/samba/log.%m
    max log size = 1000
    logging = file
    panic action = /usr/share/samba/panic-action %d

    server role = standalone server
    obey pam restrictions = yes
    unix password sync = yes

    passwd program = /usr/bin/passwd %u
    passwd chat = *Enter\

files.content:
# SNMP Footprinting

## Methods

### Snpwalk

Snmpwalk is used to query the OIDs with their information.

```bash
snmpwalk -v2c -c public <ip_address>
```

```

files.name: configuration.md
files.title: SSH Configuration and Setup
files.content:
# SSH Configuration and Setup


---

## üìÉ Default Configuration
You can get the ssh default configuration with this command :
```bash
cat /etc/ssh/sshd_config  | grep -v "#" | sed -r '/^\s*$/d'
```
Output :
```
Include /etc/ssh/sshd_config.d/*.conf
ChallengeResponseAuthentication no
UsePAM yes
X11Forwarding yes # <- THIS IS A UNSECURE PARAMETER
PrintMotd no
AcceptEnv LANG LC_*
Subsystem       sftp    /usr/lib/openssh/sftp-server
```

## ‚ùå Dangerous Settings

| Setting | Parameter |Description |

files.name: footprinting.md
files.title: SSH Footprinting
files.content:
# SSH Footprinting


## Methods

### SSH-Audit

First of all, clone ssh-audit tool and enter repository
```bash
git clone https://github.com/jtesta/ssh-audit.git && cd ssh-audit
```

Launch the tool with ip address in parameter
```bash
./ssh-audit.py <ip adress>
```

Output :
```
# general
(gen) banner: SSH-2.0-OpenSSH_8.2p1 Ubuntu-4ubuntu0.3
(gen) software: OpenSSH 8.2p1
(gen) compatibility: OpenSSH 7.4+, Dropbear SSH 2018.76+
(gen) compression: enabled (zlib@openssh.com)

files.name: footprinting.md
files.title: WINRM Footprinting
files.content:
# WINRM Footprinting

## Methods

### Scanning with Nmap

>WinRM uses TCP ports 5985 (HTTP) and 5986 (HTTPS) by default, which we can scan using Nmap. However, often we will see that only HTTP (TCP 5985) is used instead of HTTPS (TCP 5986).
```bash
nmap -sV -sC <ip_address> -p5985,5986 --disable-arp-ping -n
```

| Parameter | Description |
|-----------|-------------|
| `--disable-arp-ping` | Forces nmap to use other protocols (TCP/UDP) instead of ARP for host discovery |
| `-n` | No DNS resoluti

# Wordpress

![Banner](https://github.com/ftTower/ftTower/blob/main/assets/Cybersec-Portfolio/Courses/Web/Wordpress/banner.png)


WordPress is the most popular open source Content Management System (CMS), powering nearly one-third of all websites in the world. It can be used for multiple purposes, such as hosting blogs, forums, e-commerce, project management, document management, and much more

| **Type** | Content Managem

files.name: structure.md
files.title: Wordpress structure
headers: Default WordPress Structure (UBUNTU Linux Web server)
files.content:
# Wordpress structure

## Default WordPress File Structure

>WordPress can be installed on a Windows, Linux, or Mac OSX host.

### Default WordPress Structure (UBUNTU Linux Web server)

**WordPress requires a fully installed and configured LAMP stack (Linux operating system, Apache HTTP Server, MySQL database, and the PHP programming language) before installation on a Linux host**

all WordPress supporting files and directories will be accessible in the webroot located at **`/var/www/html`**.

#

files.name: users_roles.md
files.title: Wordpress users rules
files.content:
# Wordpress users rules

>There are five types of users in a standard WordPress installation.

| Role | Description |
|------|-------------|
| Administrator | This user has access to administrative features within the website. This includes adding and deleting users and posts, as well as editing source code. |
| Editor | An editor can publish and manage posts, including the posts of other users. |
| Author | Authors can publish and manage their own posts. |
| Contributor | These users can write
